conclusion: Determine the refraction angle when the light enters the Dawes prism and whether the light can exit from edge CD.
The angle of incidence at edge AC is 45 degrees and the refractive index of the prism glass is sqrt(2).
Using Snell's Law: n1 sin i = n2 sin r, where n1 = 1, n2 = sqrt(2), i = 45 degrees, solve for sin r.
Substitute known values: 1 * sin 45 degrees = sqrt(2) * sin r, solve for sin r.
Since sin 45 degrees = sqrt(2)/2, solve: sqrt(2)/2 = sqrt(2) * sin r, sin r = 1/2.
r = sin^(-1)(1/2) = 30 degrees. The refraction angle when the light enters the Dawes prism is 30 degrees.
Determine if the light can exit from edge CD by finding the angle of incidence at CD.
The light travels inside the prism with an angle of 30 degrees relative to the normal at AC.
The prism has angles of 45 degrees at C and D.
The angle of incidence at CD is 45 degrees - 30 degrees = 15 degrees.
Check if 15 degrees exceeds the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The critical angle is given by sin(theta_c) = 1/sqrt(2) = sqrt(2)/2, theta_c = 45 degrees.
Since 15 degrees < 45 degrees, the light does not exceed the critical angle and will not undergo total internal reflection.
The light can exit from edge CD.
The refraction angle when the light enters the Dawes prism is 30 degrees, and the light can exit from edge CD.
